executive_summary: The Metal Stamping and Forging industry had its strength tested through the current period. Volatile metal prices, macroeconomic swings and swelling employment costs pressured manufacturers. Metal Stamping and Forging industry revenue has inched downward at a CAGR of 0.5% over the past five years and is expected to total $38.6 billion in 2024, when revenue will fall by an estimated 1.8%. Focusing on quality, client elasticity and high dependency on the price of inputs helps metal stamping and forging operations differentiate themselves from competitors and substitutes.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Supply Chain Complications Early On in the Period Caused Strife
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Metal forging and stamping companies faced numerous challenges throughout the current period. In particular, business ground to a halt during the pandemic. Even for clients with continued residential construction demand, the metal supply chain withered.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Spaceflight Applications Launch Metal Demand to New Heights
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The majority of domestic commercial space launch organizations have launched vehicles into orbit through the current period, generating significant research and development revenue for metal stamping and forging companies.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Metallurgists Pass Higher Steel Prices Onto Consumers
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Despite the increasing use of nonferrous structural materials, steel manipulation accounts for the majority of metal stampers' and forgers' revenue; the material's high strength-to-cost ratio and relative workability make it the default choice for almost every project.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Sky-High Inflation And Interest Rates Delay Large Steel Projects
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Expansionary monetary policy has led to record-breaking inflation. Inflation has run rampant despite the Federal Reserve's rate hikes. Borrowing costs have ballooned, creating severe uncertainty among downstream construction and manufacturing buyers.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Metallurgists Will Rebound Over the Outlook Period
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Following volatile conditions and supply chain crises, metallurgists will enjoy a more stable outlook period with revenue growth trending toward historical growth. Easing interest rates will also support demand from most key downstream markets.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Rising Automation Will Threaten Metallurgist Jobs
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Historically, smaller metal processing factories have used manual labor to operate machines and move products between punches, forges and hammers. Labor-intensive companies manage high insurance premiums and increasing OSHA and union regulations.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Automation will reduce the cost and minimum order quantity of metal parts
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: CNC machining is still less expensive for one-off parts using metal and decreases their reliance on labor.

Precision Castparts and Howmet Aerospace have readily acquired smaller companies in an acquisition race, leading to declining establishment and enterprise figures. Leading manufacturers have increasingly targeted smaller companies to gain access to patents, strong labor forces and strategic locations near key buyers or suppliers.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Rising World Tensions Will Support Demand from Military and Defense Markets
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Metal stamping and forging companies have generated an increasing amount of revenue from defense and military contractors following the onset of Russia's invasion of Ukraine. With no clear end in sight and growing conflicts in the Middle East, the US government will increase government spending and military aid to foreign allies.

industry_definition: Operators in this industry forge, stamp and rollform ferrous (iron) and nonferrous metal products for use by other industries. Forged metal is compressed in hot or cold temperatures, while stamped metal is placed into a press to make sheets; rollformed metal is bent into shape on a set of rolls. The industry also includes powder metallurgy companies. This industry excludes the stamping of coins, cans and automotive products.
key_trends: Small shops can gain a competitive edge by offering rapid turnaround times and accommodating low minimum order volumes. The focus on local production and efficiency appeals to client businesses that prioritize employee time-saving measures and increased workplace safety over mere cost savings.

Competitive metallurgists must prioritize producing high-quality products to maintain their reputation and customer trust. By implementing stringent measurement and inspection processes for every part produced, proactive manufacturers can avoid potential litigation issues.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Airplanes, helicopters, spacecraft and other aircraft manufacturing lead demand for stamped and forged metal products. The high strength of stamped steel, titanium and aluminum is ideal for modern airframes. General Electric, the manufacturer of many aircraft engines worldwide, uses stamped metal as a critical component of its design. Demand has climbed as the economy recovers from the pandemic. For example, pent-up travel demand has encouraged airliners to upgrade fleets; private spending on space vehicles has increased significantly.

Military and government demand for aircraft, missiles and NASA projects represents a ballooning market for metal stamping and forging companies. Contractors spend liberally on high-quality stamped metal orders and focus more on long-term value than sticker prices. Producers tend to focus on a single industry market, with large contractors tending to move toward military orders; for example, Howmet Aerospace and Allegheny Technologies regularly generate between 50.0% and 75.0% of total revenue by servicing the aerospace and defense market. Climbing world tensions have led to elevated global military spending. Eastern and Northern European countries have stockpiled arms in response to Russia's invasion of Ukraine. Similarly, Taiwan, Japan and other Asian countries have increased demand following China's military activity in the South China Sea and Taiwan. The war in Israel has also added volatility to military markets.

This market includes manufacturers of tractors, seeding and harvesting equipment, farm dairy machinery and other agricultural equipment. This market also comprises manufacturers of heavy construction machinery and mining equipment, including forklifts, cranes and backhoes. Agricultural equipment manufacturers have struggled with oscillating crop prices and reduced spending by downstream farmers and have curbed their demand for new forged and stamped products.

Metal forming for military weapons production is a niche market for specialized metallurgists. Large producers with defense clearances commonly support this market. Like military aerospace markets, projects in this market are classified, making it difficult to determine the range of current projects and demand opportunities. Rising tensions and war outbreaks have assuredly led to production spikes.

Production of industrial manufacturing machines and inputs for other manufactured goods takes another fifth of formed metal products. Conveyor belts, processing machines and other factory goods benefit from the strength of stamped metal, as production lines focus on reliability. COVID-19 damaged demand for industrial expansion, stalling demand for metallurgists serving industrial markets. Industrial production will rebound through the outlook period as the economy recovers from the pandemic, creating stable demand for metal stampers and forgers.

Mass-produced oil and gas machinery, rock drilling hardware and fluid valves use stamped metal to lower costs while retaining a durable product. These industries also benefit from stamped metal suppliers' stringent product quality tests. These markets provide stable and varied demand for metal stamping and forging companies. Even so, these markets represent a muted portion of their overall revenue.

products_and_services.product_description: Manufacturers make stamped metal products by pushing, pulling and punching cold metal sheets into a desired shape. Metal-stamping products include job stampings (except automotive), metal-spinning products and pressed-metal end products.

Manufacturers make forged metal products by heating a thick slab of metal until it structurally weakens and then pounding the metal into shape. Product revenue for this segment is divided into ferrous (iron and steel) forging.

Manufacturers make forged metal products by heating a thick slab of metal until it structurally weakens and then pounding the metal into shape. Product revenue for this segment is divided into nonferrous (aluminum and titanium) forging.
Manufacturers make rollformed metal products by cold-rolling metal sheets together and fusing the ends into a cylinder. The oil and gas extraction industries most commonly use rollformed products.
Powder metallurgy works by melting a metal powder into the desired shape and cooling it. Companies often purchase separate supplies of powdered metal from metal manufacturers.

Metal manufacturers work with clients for specialty contracts to design the final product. This segment also includes engineering services, metal transportation costs, and other value-added services beyond the quoted price of the metal.

tier_1_suppliers: Tool & Hardware Wholesaling in the US
Industrial Machinery & Equipment Wholesaling in the US
Iron & Steel Manufacturing in the US
Screw, Nut & Bolt Manufacturing in the US
Copper Rolling, Drawing & Extruding in the US
tier_1_buyers: Aircraft, Engine & Parts Manufacturing in the US
Structural Metal Product Manufacturing in the US
Automobile Metal Stamping in the US
Sheet Metal, Window & Door Manufacturing in the US
Boiler & Heat Exchanger Manufacturing in the US

The high strength of stamped steel, titanium and aluminum is ideal for modern airframes. General Electric, the manufacturer of many aircraft engines worldwide, uses stamped metal as a critical component of its design. Demand has climbed as the economy recovers from the pandemic. For example, pent-up travel demand has encouraged airliners to upgrade fleets; private spending on space vehicles has increased significantly.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Military and government demand for aircraft, missiles and NASA projects represents a ballooning market for metal stamping and forging companies. Contractors spend liberally on high-quality stamped metal orders and focus more on long-term value than sticker prices. Producers tend to focus on a single industry market, with large contractors tending to move toward military orders; for example, Howmet Aerospace and Allegheny Technologies regularly generate between 50.0% and 75.0% of total revenue by servicing the aerospace and defense market. Climbing world tensions have led to elevated global military spending. Eastern and Northern European countries have stockpiled arms in response to Russia's invasion of Ukraine. Similarly, Taiwan, Japan and other Asian countries have increased demand following China's military activity in the South China Sea and Taiwan. The war in Israel has also added volatility to military markets.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Off-Highway and Agriculture Markets Regularly Purchase New Equipment
demand_determinants.determinant_description: This market includes manufacturers of tractors, seeding and harvesting equipment, farm dairy machinery and other agricultural equipment. This market also comprises manufacturers of heavy construction machinery and mining equipment, including forklifts, cranes and backhoes. Agricultural equipment manufacturers have struggled with oscillating crop prices and reduced spending by downstream farmers and have curbed their demand for new forged and stamped products.

Metal forming for military weapons production is a niche market for specialized metallurgists. Large producers with defense clearances commonly support this market. Like military aerospace markets, projects in this market are classified, making it difficult to determine the range of current projects and demand opportunities. Rising tensions and war outbreaks have assuredly led to production spikes.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Industrial Manufacturing Markets Benefit From The Economy's Post-Pandemic Recovery
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Production of industrial manufacturing machines and inputs for other manufactured goods takes another fifth of formed metal products. Conveyor belts, processing machines and other factory goods benefit from the strength of stamped metal, as production lines focus on reliability. COVID-19 damaged demand for industrial expansion, stalling demand for metallurgists serving industrial markets. Industrial production will rebound through the outlook period as the economy recovers from the pandemic, creating stable demand for metal stampers and forgers.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Imports Outpace Exports of Stamped Metal Products
international_trade_points.trade_description: Chinese and Mexican imports represent leading contributors to climbing import penetration. These low-cost producers benefit from lower labor costs and fewer environmental regulations to flood markets with inexpensive, often generic products.

In 2018, the Trump administration invoked Section 232 restrictions from the Trade Expansion Act to impose tariffs on imported steel and aluminum. The federal government applied these tariffs globally, imposing a 25.0% duty on steel and a 10.0% duty on aluminum imported into the United States.

international_trade_points.trade_title: COMPANIES MOSTLY EXPORT HIGH-QUALITY STAMPED GOODS TO NEARBY NATIONS
international_trade_points.trade_description: Higher wages in the United States give national producers an advantage in producing high-quality, high-volume stamped metal goods. Manufacturers primarily transport these stamped metal goods by railcar to Canada and Mexico, with France and the UK representing a far smaller fraction of total demand.

international_trade_points.trade_title: THE US'S COMPARABLY HIGH MINIMUM WAGE MAKES IT A WEAK EXPORTER FOR MOST STAMPED METALS
international_trade_points.trade_description: Foreign manufacturers can complete metal product production at a fraction of the cost in many nations worldwide since most countries have fewer labor regulations.

business_locations.location_description: One-third of metal stamping companies are situated in regions historically or currently dominated by steel mills, reducing travel costs for procuring bulk steel. These companies often establish direct contracts with local steel and iron manufacturers, ensuring easier access to raw materials and fostering strong business relationships. Metal forgers in the Great Lakes region benefit from reduced transport costs because of their proximity to major automotive production centers. This strategic location ensures efficient supply chain operations, creating strong relationships with key manufacturing buyers and suppliers and enhancing overall industry competitiveness.

The Southeast's plentiful land and labor supply has made it an attractive destination for metal manufacturers seeking to establish operations. The region also offers cost-effective access to energy resources, incentivizing businesses to set up shop and capitalize on these economic advantages. The Southeast's metal stampers cater significantly to the agricultural sector, producing ample farming equipment to meet the demands of its numerous farmers. Also, the region's dense population drives extensive construction and manufacturing efforts, bolstering demand for metal stamping in various industries.

Metal shops in the Mid-Atlantic region benefit from their strategic proximity to New Jersey and New York ports, which enable efficient global distribution of bulk goods. The area's robust trade relationships with Canadian manufacturers in Quebec and Ontario enhance their competitive advantage in the market. Pennsylvania's rich history in steel production has fostered a robust network of skilled labor and advanced facilities, making it a prime location for metal stamping and forging companies. By using the state's well-established infrastructure, these companies can efficiently produce high-quality steel products to meet national and international demands.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) enforces safety regulations to protect metal stamping and forging workers. These include requirements for machine guarding, proper handling of hazardous materials and the use of protective gear.

The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) regulates emissions and waste disposal in the metal stamping and forging industry. Facilities must obtain air and water discharge permits, follow guidelines to limit pollutants and implement hazardous waste management protocols.

The Clean Air Act regulates air pollutant emissions from industrial facilities, including those involved in metal stamping and forging. Companies must obtain permits for various emissions sources, adhere to National Ambient Air Quality Standards (NAAQS) and implement control technologies to minimize emissions.

The release of hazardous air pollutants. Regular monitoring, reporting and compliance with Maximum Achievable Control Technology (MACT) standards are essential to reduce environmental harm and protect public health.

OSHA also regulates occupational noise exposure in manufacturing industries like metal stamping and forging. Employers must implement engineering controls and provide hearing protection to limit workers' exposure to high noise levels.

The RCRA governs the disposal of solid and hazardous waste in the metal stamping and forging industry. Facilities must classify and manage waste according to strict guidelines, including proper storage, transportation and disposal methods.

Companies in the metal stamping and forging industry that produce defense-related components must comply with ITAR. These regulations control the export and import of defense articles and services to safeguard US national security.

This regulation mandates that companies in the metal stamping and forging industry disclose the origins of specific minerals, such as tin, tungsten, tantalum and gold. Often sourced from conflict-affected areas, these materials must be traced to ensure they do not finance armed conflict.

regulations_points.regulation_title: NATIONAL EMISSION STANDARDS FOR HAZARDOUS AIR POLLUTANTS (NESHAP)
regulations_points.regulation_description: Under the Clean Air Act, NESHAP sets specific standards for hazardous air pollutants from the metal stamping and forging industry. Companies must monitor and control emissions of toxic substances, such as heavy metals and volatile organic compounds, using the best available technology.

The TSCA requires metal stamping and forging companies to track and report the use and management of industrial chemicals. This includes evaluating the potential environmental and health risks of chemicals used in manufacturing processes, maintaining detailed records and adhering to regulations regarding their safe use, storage and disposal.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Entrants must strictly follow OSHA safety regulations and implement a comprehensive waste disposal management system. They must also avoid infringing upon existing copyrights while managing noise, waste and other environmental factors in compliance with legal standards.

Creating structural materials for clients involves advanced machinery, with the type of metal and product sizes significantly impacting start-up costs. Also, the manufacturing process demands higher energy consumption, increasing operational expenses.

Differentiating factors such as price, quality, turnaround time and minimum volumes are critical for metal producers. Aerospace and military markets, in particular, are hesitant to switch suppliers because of the substantial investments required to certify new metal components.

Skilled craftsmen are essential for managing and maintaining machinery, ensuring smooth operations even in highly automated environments. Newly established companies often find hiring these well-trained workers cost-prohibitive, whereas larger companies can offset labor costs with substantial capital investments and advanced technology.

basis_points.basis_description: Small shops can gain a competitive edge by offering rapid turnaround times and accommodating low minimum order volumes. The focus on local production and efficiency appeals to client businesses that prioritize employee time-saving measures and increased workplace safety over mere cost savings.

Competitive metallurgists must prioritize producing high-quality products to maintain their reputation and customer trust. By implementing stringent measurement and inspection processes for every part produced, proactive manufacturers can avoid potential litigation issues and justify commanding higher prices in the market.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Local Metal Shops Control Most Forging Supply
concentration_points.concentration_description: Despite the three largest forged metal product manufacturers, Precision Castparts, Howmet Aerospace and Allegheny Technologies, controlling a significant portion of industry contracts, small metal shops employing fewer than 50 individuals still produce most metal products.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Leading Companies Drive Merger and Acquisition Trends
concentration_points.concentration_description: Precision Castparts and Howmet Aerospace have been highly active in merger and acquisition markets through the current period to bolster local production near client sites. Berkshire Hathaway also acquired Precision Castparts.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Breakdowns and Skyrocketing Oil Prices Caused Purchasing Costs to Balloon Post-Pandemic
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: These high prices have pressured profit. Prices have receded as upstream suppliers adapt to the Russian invasion of Ukraine and other exogenous supply shocks. Many companies also maintain contracts with key suppliers to limit unexpected changes. Still, profit is unable to quickly recover due to these constant fluctuations.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Skilled craftsmen are essential for managing and maintaining machinery, ensuring smooth operations even in highly automated environments. Newly established companies often find hiring these well-trained workers cost-prohibitive, whereas larger companies can offset labor costs with substantial capital investments and advanced technology.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Stronger Industrial Production Will Shield the Industry From Volatility
volatility_points.volatility_description: Various sectors, from farming and manufacturing to aerospace, use stamped and forged metal products. When these enterprises falter, potential customers shy away from extensive metal purchases and reuse existing infrastructure.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Manufacturers Rely on Commercial and Military Aerospace Demand
volatility_points.volatility_description: Aerospace companies plan years ahead of time, smoothing growth in good and bad economic environments. These long-term contracts provide stable demand for manufacturers.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Many metal manufacturers struggle to scale production capacity with demand, as metal manipulation processes are relatively dangerous and complicated. An entirely new building wing might be necessary if more production lines are needed.

Extreme forces and temperatures involved with metal manufacturing have limited the deployment of computer sensors in smaller factories. The production of resilient computers, sensors and networks has enabled even small metal shops to remotely monitor their equipment.

FAQs.question: How is your company affected by rising imports?
FAQs.answer: Due to the high technological and quality requirements this and other industrial markets demand, in addition to the fast turnaround times required, imports have remained limited.

FAQs.question: How have imports from low-wage countries like China and Mexico impacted your operations?
FAQs.answer: Since China has much lower wage costs, operators in the country are able to produce their products at a lower cost point than domestic operators. China also maintains massive steel production pipelines, allowing for tighter vertical integration. To remain competitive, domestic operators must lower their prices to entice downstream markets, thus diminishing their returns. Alternatively, domestic operators can increase quality, market effectively, or go after government contracts, which often shun international competition.

FAQs.question: How has your company sought to lessen commodity price risk?
FAQs.answer: The world price of steel, nonferrous metals and other metal inputs has been wildly volatile. Operators must be able to sell products at competitive prices to remain relevant, placing downward pressure on revenue and profit. Fixed-price deals with suppliers are becoming increasingly common to reduce risk and overall costs.

FAQs.question: Has your company explored acquisition opportunities in areas with well-established infrastructure?
FAQs.answer: Larger players have been acquiring counterparts that can serve as complementary subsidiaries for their operations.

FAQs.question: How is your company leveraging new technology?
FAQs.answer: Influenced by climbing electrical rates and high natural gas prices, manufacturers are increasingly adopting new technologies that provide greater efficiencies in the use of energy. Companies with enough liquidity may want to consider implementing energy-saving technology now, as regulations restricting industrial burning of fossil fuels are likely to be implemented in the next decade.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs through automation over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: Some operators have invested in equipment that increases automation, leading industry wages to decline marginally during the period. Due to high labor costs, many industrial operators are investing in robotics, sensors and other systems to decrease labor reliance. After the global chip shortage subsides, prices for these systems are anticipated to fall.

FAQs.question: How does your company stay ahead of regulations, such as energy-efficiency standards and tariffs?
FAQs.answer: Most companies have developed extensive environmental, health and safety policies and procedures that include the proper handling, storage and disposal of hazardous materials. Sending employees to attend in-person or virtual trade shows will help keep your company current and multiply lobbying power for industry-wide.

FAQs.question: How have international tariffs impacted your ability to import and export products?
FAQs.answer: International levies typically impede free trade and increase the cost of doing business. Operators that produce goods which are price elastic and can effectively pass on these expenses will earn consistently greater profit. If these tariffs affect your business significantly, you may want to try inducing demand or supply in non-traditional regions to save on costs in the long term.

FAQs.question: How do your company's profit margins compare to your main competitors'?
FAQs.answer: There is a large variation in the average profit margin for the industry and the larger players. Larger operators have been able to consistently post operating margin in the double-digits. Studying competitors' public documents, including 10-Ks and Annual Reports may give insights into their future projects and differentiating strategies.

FAQs.question: How has input price volatility affected profit margin?
FAQs.answer: The fluctuation in the price of key inputs causes smaller operators to have a difficult time competitively pricing their products, as they are unable to secure steady price points from suppliers. Smaller operators may consider networking together to aggregate key inputs and negotiate more favorable terms with metal suppliers.

FAQs.question: Are you able to leverage economies of scale? What is your budget for expanding operations?
FAQs.answer: A key success factor for industry operators is their ability to increase the scale of business production and reduce costs. Businesses that can efficiently scale production will generally prosper, so long as sufficient demand for its products exists. Alternatively, specialization in high-markup custom products is a path to profitability taken by many smaller operators. While companies using each method have prospered, mixing high-volume and low-volume manufacturing will likely cause management challenges.

FAQs.question: How do you maintain product quality? How much of your revenue is derived from the aerospace and defense industries?
FAQs.answer: All suppliers that supply the aerospace and defense industries are required to meet numerous quality standards to qualify as a preferred and long-term supplier to the original equipment manufacturer (OEM). While the regulations associated with producing these products are generally more stringent, companies that manufacture high-value metal goods tend to earn greater profit. Demonstrating high product quality will also protect your markets from choosing international products instead, which typically have lower quality standards.

FAQs.question: Do you have contacts with key distributors and end-users? How does your company go about establishing new contracts?
FAQs.answer: Consolidation among downstream markets means that upstream supplies may be rewarded with long-term, sole-source contracts. Try forming multi-year, fixed-price contracts with key buyers and sellers, especially in the volatile metals markets.

FAQs.question: How have volatile steel prices affected your company's revenue and profit? Are you able to pass on steel costs to downstream consumers?
FAQs.answer: High steel prices raise input purchase costs, but also boost the value of end-product inventory. Conversely, inventory is devalued when prices drop, hurting selling prices and revenue. Rising steel prices are favorable to this industry's performance because they indicate growing demand.

FAQs.question: How much of your business depends on aviation markets? Are you considering diversification to protect against future air transport market crashes?
FAQs.answer: When considering future corporate purchases, those that diversify end-markets into more stable military contracts (such as ordnance) or alternative markets may increase long-term revenue stability.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor changes in the trade index? How do you take advantage of increased competition from abroad? Does your company market internationally?
FAQs.answer: The trade-weighted index (TWI) measures the power of the United States dollar to purchase more goods than currencies of other nations. When the index increases, the dollar is getting more powerful, leading to pressure to import cheap inputs from abroad. Similarly, a decrease in the index incentivizes national production and exports. Companies must monitor all tariffs and currency valuations of import and export destination countries. Consider diversification into nations with weaker TWIs for inputs (metals) and stronger TWIs for end-markets.
